Our immune cells usually detect "faulty" cells based on proteins. Either ones stuck to the outside of the cell membrane or proteins that the cell is actively producing. For example the cells at the base of your fingernails should be producing Keratin. If the immune cells find a weirdly shaped protein, or perhaps some of your lung cells start producing a ton of Keratin, the immune cells will kill the offenders straight away. The invisibility cloak can happen when the cancer cells mutate to grow out of control, but also that growth does not include producing a bunch of recognizably incorrect proteins. The immune cells just stroll on by thinking "yep, these proteins belong here" or sometimes the proteins are so particularly shaped that the immune cells can't even get ahold of them to check what they are.

"defective" is not the appropriate term. Many genetic variations are similar partial deletions and some have very powerful benefits in some situations. It's not "defective"    It's a variation with a different set of interactions with other genes, etc some beneficial some detrimental some neutral. Any gene that is only detrimental will get rapidly selected out of the population and occur only at about the natural mutation rate.

You can search up 'Lentiviral Gene Therapy' if you want to learn more about it. Essentially yes, something like Crispr (but not Crispr) is used to genetically engineer a retrovirus with a specific gene code which is then inserted into a supply of patient cells (usually stem cells, marrow etc) ex vivo. The retrovirus inserts the selected gene into the genome of the cells so it's a lifetime treatment, when those stem cells or whatever eventually undergo mitosis in the body because the medicine is integrated into the genome the new cells also carry the cure. Really interesting stuff.

Well they literally did edit a persons genes. Editing the patients entire genetic code would be a stupid way of trying to fix cancer. The cancerous cells are already modified via mutation. To fix that they would have to figure out exactly what that mutation was, (not an easy feat) target the fix to only hit them, and then pump her full of whatever method they used for this. (Also, distributing that fix to all of the cancer cells is another big problem.) Or they could just edit a few T cells and inject them. It is much more elegant, and much less dangerous. Not a changer her eye color and make her a genius change. But it is significant and amazing and absolutely is gene editing.

Also as long as her partner isn't also a carrier of the faulty gene then the child can't display it because its recessive. Just very unlucky for the parents to meet each other and have both children inherit the double recessive. Personalised genetic medicine seems to be the direction healthcare is going in the UK (source, studying Biomedical Science in Scotland) which should catch on to this stuff before a terminal diagnosis is made. Funnily enough I actually did a project on this type of treatment (Lentiviral gene therapy) just a couple months ago, was very unexpected to see it in the news. There have been a lot of other successful clinical trials too which cure various genetic diseases if you want to search up 'Lentiviral Gene Therapy' on PubMed.

Our immune cells usually detect "faulty" cells based on proteins. Either ones stuck to the outside of the cell membrane or proteins that the cell is actively producing. For example the cells at the base of your fingernails should be producing Keratin. If the immune cells find a weirdly shaped protein, or perhaps some of your lung cells start producing a ton of Keratin, the immune cells will kill the offenders straight away. The invisibility cloak can happen when the cancer cells mutate to grow out of control, but also that growth does not include producing a bunch of recognizably incorrect proteins. The immune cells just stroll on by thinking "yep, these proteins belong here" or sometimes the proteins are so particularly shaped that the immune cells can't even get ahold of them to check what they are.

I had a discussion about this with my audiologist and surgeon when I got my CI over the summer. Apparently, it would depend on the integrity of the tissue in the cochlea, which tends to get "scraped up" when the electrode coil is inserted (CI's just need the neurons in the cochlea to function, the other tissue isn't important).  CI companies are starting to design the electrode coil to minimize the damage to the tissue, both to save residual hearing and to allow the patient to benefit from future hearing loss therapies. However, unless you have one of the top CI surgeons, (That's not what they are called, but I forget what specialty these surgeons train in) preserving tissue is a crap shoot. That being said, CI in one ear and regrown hair cells in the other? We would be freakin' gods...

Not really. The problem with CRISPR is that it doesn't do much good against multigenic traits. By that I mean, you have genes in your body that work together to do certain things, and even parts of your DNA that don't make any proteins but regulate other pathways. Things like height, intelligence, even hair color are decided by more than one gene in your body, and are decided by several genes and their associated regulatory mechanisms. CRISPR can't affect every one of those steps, it's actually a very simple system (relatively).

One of the major functions of the human immune system is to actively police and destroy significant mutations. A complex body like ours does NOT want rapid mutation. If our cells were to mutate at the speed of a single-celled organism we would very quickly wind up with loads of deformities like what we see with animals exposed to high doses of nuclear radiation. Cancers come from relatively rare mutations that our immune system cannot recognize and destroy on sight. From then on, it's game over. The cancer has achieved an invisibility cloak to keep on mutating unchecked, while our healthy cells are still policing themselves to stay in line.

Our immune cells usually detect "faulty" cells based on proteins. Either ones stuck to the outside of the cell membrane or proteins that the cell is actively producing. For example the cells at the base of your fingernails should be producing Keratin. If the immune cells find a weirdly shaped protein, or perhaps some of your lung cells start producing a ton of Keratin, the immune cells will kill the offenders straight away. The invisibility cloak can happen when the cancer cells mutate to grow out of control, but also that growth does not include producing a bunch of recognizably incorrect proteins. The immune cells just stroll on by thinking "yep, these proteins belong here" or sometimes the proteins are so particularly shaped that the immune cells can't even get ahold of them to check what they are.

Well they literally did edit a persons genes. Editing the patients entire genetic code would be a stupid way of trying to fix cancer. The cancerous cells are already modified via mutation. To fix that they would have to figure out exactly what that mutation was, (not an easy feat) target the fix to only hit them, and then pump her full of whatever method they used for this. (Also, distributing that fix to all of the cancer cells is another big problem.) Or they could just edit a few T cells and inject them. It is much more elegant, and much less dangerous. Not a changer her eye color and make her a genius change. But it is significant and amazing and absolutely is gene editing.

You're right about that it isn't itself a cure, but royalties from a tech that valuable are crucial to the continuation of academic research. Nonprofits and university-associated research institutions cost a lot of money to maintain, particularly things like core facilities and maintenance. They could in principle charge all of that to the labs, but if you're going to attract top-level researchers, you need to keep the overhead and indirect costs reasonable. Therefore, royalty streams from IP make up a sizable portion of their operating budgets. (I work at one such nonprofit, and this is a well-known fact of life.)

The lure of high profits for a cure are you wife's best chance. These profits require patent protection.  There is a reason why all the new cures get developed in the U.S., and unfortunately it's the same reason why drugs cost so damn much.

She would likely pass on the original gene. Gene therapy generally targets only the specific cells that express the trait being treated so the original DNA sequence would remain unchanged in the remaining cells.  As an example, if blindness was being treated with gene therapy, the cells in the eyes would be targeted but liver cells, bones, etc would not, even though they still have the same genetic code. As far as I know, the only way that gene therapy results could be passed to offspring is if the alterations took place in an embryo before implantation.

Not enhancements in Gattaca.  They select the most optimal of genetic pairings of genomes between the parents.  So all the genes are there in the parents, but they choose that one in a billion chance offspring that would result in the most optimal combination of the two parents DNA

I am a biomedical research who has worked for a few years on gene editing. Your comment is mostly right however one major correction is that this treatment is not correcting any gene, it is simply deleting a gene. This is very different and much easier currently then correcting or inserting a broken or missing gene. For some diseases, deleting a broken gene is enough for a cure, for others this would not be the case. Our ability to edit DNA bases or to do CRISPR gene knock-in, as opposed to knock-out is currently very poor, at least when it comes to efficiently doing this in a large proportion of cells with no off-target effects. I do believe our abilities will improve rapidly. Just wanted to be clear about the difference between these two things.

Our immune cells usually detect "faulty" cells based on proteins. Either ones stuck to the outside of the cell membrane or proteins that the cell is actively producing. For example the cells at the base of your fingernails should be producing Keratin. If the immune cells find a weirdly shaped protein, or perhaps some of your lung cells start producing a ton of Keratin, the immune cells will kill the offenders straight away. The invisibility cloak can happen when the cancer cells mutate to grow out of control, but also that growth does not include producing a bunch of recognizably incorrect proteins. The immune cells just stroll on by thinking "yep, these proteins belong here" or sometimes the proteins are so particularly shaped that the immune cells can't even get ahold of them to check what they are.

one of the exciting parts of this study was that the CRISPR-Cas9 system didn't cleave at any off-target DNA sites and therefore didn't make any unintended changes to genomes of the zygotes. this is a pretty big issue in any attempt to use CRISPR, but it's important to note that just because the authors got super high-specificity in this study with this gene doesn't mean we'll see similar success with other genes. there's still a lot of work out before CRISPR becomes truly reliable for genome-wide editing

I'm not an expert, but my understanding is that the immunity to the adenovirus is relatively short-lived. "The Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium is a principle stating that the genetic variation in a population will remain constant from one generation to the next in the absence of disturbing factors. When mating is random in a large population with no disruptive circumstances, the law predicts that both genotype and allele frequencies will remain constant because they are in equilibrium." In a population not affected by natural selection and by differential mating preferences the frequency of a mutation will remain the same,  so no "bad genetic spread until we all get genetic disorder genes"

This approach, of using an adenovirus as a vector, also was responsible for the death of an 18 year old named Jesse Gelsinger back in 1999. Jesse had a metabolic disorder that was tough to live with but not life threatening. His death set back the advancement of gene therapy by a very long time by turning the public against it, but also making scientists realize that their understanding was naive and more work needed to be done. What happened in the case of Jesse was that the adenovirus was recognized by the immune system, and an immune response was led against it. There was no "trojan horse" - his body saw the virus immediately and since they injected him with so much of it, it basically led to organ failure.

This is very untrue. CF is caused by a loss-of-function mutation in the CFTR chloride channel. This causes a lack of chloride uptake into cells in many tissues which leads to thickening of mucus in the lungs and of secretions in organs like the pancreas. Researchers know exactly which gene to target and that a functional channel would restore normal function. As others have mentioned, targeting all lung cells (or enough to make a difference) is the current issue with crispr-cas9 technology.

Prenatal diagnosis of Fragile X is invasive (needle inside the uterus) and not routinely offered. Parents with mental disability or known family history of Fragile X Syndrome may be offered screening. Most newborns are physically normal at birth and cognitive differences are not seen until around six months of age. After that, physical signs and further cognitive underdevelopment become more noticeable. Incidence published is in newborns. However, there are also some carrier prevalence studies out there.

Gene therapy generally targets only the specific cells that express the trait being treated so the original DNA sequence would remain unchanged in the remaining cells.  As an example, if blindness was being treated with gene therapy, the cells in the eyes would be targeted but liver cells, bones, etc would not, even though they still have the same genetic code. A risk of cancer due to such treatment can come from another source. Having telomerase activity in cells that would otherwise not have it gives cancer one less step to go through in creating an immortal cell line.  Cells that turn cancerous but stay without the telomerase activity have their replication arrested when their telomeres are depleted. It is a, sort of, safety meter that gets depleted too quickly by cancerous cells.

One of the major functions of the human immune system is to actively police and destroy significant mutations. A complex body like ours does NOT want rapid mutation. If our cells were to mutate at the speed of a single-celled organism we would very quickly wind up with loads of deformities like what we see with animals exposed to high doses of nuclear radiation. Cancers come from relatively rare mutations that our immune system cannot recognize and destroy on sight. From then on, it's game over. The cancer has achieved an invisibility cloak to keep on mutating unchecked, while our healthy cells are still policing themselves to stay in line.

This is a horrible idea. Telomerase activation is a key step in the immortalization of cancer cells.  The fact that the mice showed no apparent increase in cancer does not remedy this fact. A paper by Weinberg which characterized the species specific requirements for immortalization of cells shows that mouse cells do not require telomerase activity, while humans do. Therefore, taking a gene that is dispensable in the immortalization process for mice and making judgements about humans, where telomerase has been shown to be critical is inherently flawed

That's interesting. There are certainly easier methods of producing an auxotroph, though. Even the mutations you described can occur. If a mutation results in the substitution of a critical amino acid for another AA with similar properties, the mutant organism can be viable. My point is that all regions of the genome are subject to mutation. Each base pair has to have a strong selection pressure against its modification for it to be conserved. The initial idea that you could protect an artificial nucleotide 'code' in a highly conserved region of the genome, is flawed, because that code wouldn't be affected by the selection pressures acting on the surrounding DNA sequence - or it'd be eliminated by them.

An international team of researchers led by scientists at the University of California San Diego School of Medicine reported that a gene therapy that inhibits targeted nerve cell signaling effectively reduced neuropathic pain in mice with spinal cord or peripheral nerve injuries with no detectable side effects. The results, which were published in the online edition of Molecular Therapy on May 5, 2022, suggest a possible new treatment option for a condition that may affect more than half of individuals with spinal cord injuries. Neuropathy involves damage or dysfunction in nerves elsewhere in the body, typically resulting in chronic or debilitating numbness, tingling, muscle weakness, and pain.

The CRISPR method involves recognition of a specific sequence of DNA bases, and replaces that specific sequence with one that is hardcoded into the CRISPR. In essence a CRISPR recognizes "atataggccat" and replaces it with "aataacgcgtt". This could pose an issue if the sequence is very short, but CRISPR sequences are rather long, which should practically eliminate any chance of modification in an unwanted location.

It's pretty simple, a bunch of random changes happen, and the ones that make it more stable carry on and persist simply because the more stable chromosome is better at surviving.  The random changes that lead to less stable chromosome survive less as they degenerate more and lead to genetic problems that lessen survival chances.   The chromosome doesn't know to change to a more stable form any more than water in a river knows the way to the ocean, it just does it because that's the way it is pushed by the basic pressure of natural selection, just as the water goes to the ocean by just the basic force of gravity.

It's not so much that our own immune system's are destroying the treatments. The way to preferably attack and kill "unwanted" cells as opposed to healthy cells in our body is to target unique aspects of the "unwanted" cells. As an example, bacterial have something called a cell wall that human cells do not. So when we get infected with certain bacteria, we can give patients Penicillin, which targets the cell wall of bacteria and leaves our cells relatively unscathed. The problem with cancer cells is that they have developed from our own, original cells. There are less unique aspects of the cell to target since many of those aspects are shared with our healthy cells. There are a lot of cancer drugs that target DNA related processes, but of course all of our cells have DNA and this is where the "killing the patient" comes from.

The eyes have long been known to be immune privileged, along with the testes. The key to this or the already released Spinraza, is early detection of the disease.  Lack of SMN protein causes motor neuron disfunction and eventually death of the neuron. And this process can happen very rapidly, which is why average life expectancy of an untreated child with SMA type I is 18 months.  These drugs allow more full length SMN protein to be created.   If this correction happens in time, the neuron disfunction may be reversed.  But this does not resurrect dead motor neurons.  Children must start treatment immediately after birth to achieve the results in this video.  SMA must be added to the newborn screening panel of every state. It is morally irresponsible not to, now that a treatment exists.

Yes all gene edits were made intentionally. Genes known to be particularly "pig-like" and therefore more antigenic to human immune cells were knocked out. Human genes which facilitate immune acceptance were edited in. It's a very co-ordinated science.

Do you understand that different viruses have different viral proteins, RNA, and DNA fragments? Those with reverse transcriptase proteins vs those without. Some viruses can penetrate the nuclear membrane in order to interdigitate with the humane genome. Many cannot and just replicate in the cytoplasm and never touch human DNA. It all depends on their replication mechanisms. mRNA is a very short lived macromolecule. It gets digested into nucleotides after being translated. It requires proteins in the cytoplasm to translate it. Multiple (and different) proteins are needed to interdigitate RNA with DNA. It has to be reverse transcribed for one into DNA before it can bind to DNA bc RNA has uracil as a nucleotide instead of thymine and dna error proteins would kick out uracil-adenine hydrogen bonded base pairs from a dna double strand if it was found. I can go on.

Clearly OP didn't read the article. The entire point wasn't that cancer dies when exposed to algae, it was that scientists have found a way to genetically engineer unicellular algae to form anti-body binding protein. This allows them to use the algae (it's structure really, it won't matter if the algae is alive as long as it's till intact) as a delivery method for drugs that do the actual killing without also killing all the surrounding cells.  This research is the sort of thing the OP is looking for, it's a delivery system, not a drug. But it's faster to snark.

Each time a cell divides, a bit of telomere is removed. When there is no more telomere, the cell stops dividing. The thing is, this process is put in place by the body in order to prevent DNA degeneration (cancer, tumor). So this process doesn't really help unless the patient is extremely healthy. However it could be used in conjunction with CRISPR (gene editing) to prevent DNA degeneration while increasing the number of times cells can divide. There are many difficulties with implementing artificial hearts (and other organs). the conditions inside the body tend to degrade foreign objects, so metals can be corroded, proteins and cells deposit on surfaces, etc. You can have clots build up in the artificial heart, so you will need to be on an anti-clotting medication which comes with a host of other issues. Tons of fibrous, essentially scar tissue tends to build up around implanted objects. There's the problem of supplying power to an artificial heart as well, there are other implants required to power it along with running wires through the skin to an external power source. Having essentially a permanently open wound site can allow infection. Typically mechanical heart valves aren't very efficient either. And modern artificial hearts might be moving towards pulseless, constant flows. Would you find it weird having no pulse?

Decades of research means we now know a lot about what different genes do, and how they interact. A lot of this has been determined experimentally. For example, if we knock this gene out (meaning it no longer functions) what does a cell do, and how does this affect the expression of other genes? By combining a lot of this knowledge we can build computer models that use the known gene interactions, and maybe even make predictions on what genes might interact. Doing this you might find genes that regulate a bunch of other genes. Add some knowledge of the cancer you are researching, and you might find some promising target genes (i.e., ones that are upregulated in your cancer but not in healthy genes). Then you need to do some actual experimentation to validate your findings of course.

On top of that, once you start changing simple things, it opens the door to less necessary and potentially unethical changes. Sure, we eventually could be superhumans, but we could just as easily be made intentionally handicapped so as to not compete with those superhumans.

As of now, the two new nucleotides they made has no translation into amino acids therefore serves no purpose.  The process of protein synthesis relies on other nucleotides called tRNA which bind to specific amino acids.  Since tRNA binds to a specific sequence of mRNA which itself was derived from DNA, there is no natural tRNA molecules that bind to the new custom nucleotides.  They are essentially useless unless we accompany them with new tRNA's that is complementary to the new sequence.  Even then,  it would make no difference in our protein structure unless we design a new amino acid along with it.

I cannot find any evidence for the use of inosine in any fungal genome. Furthermore, incorporation of inosine into the genome is inherently unstable because inosine can stably base pair with any of the canonical nucleotides. This will result in the eventual loss of inosine from the genome after a certain amount of generations. Inosine is important in degeneracy, however, in the transcriptome. See adenosine to inosine RNA editing. Ornithine is not a nucleotide, it is a non-proteinogenic amino acid. Susceptibility to cycloheximide is not inherent to fungi. Another interesting aspect of non-natural amino acid, and now non-natural base, incorporation is that we can get increasingly orthogonal biology in engineered systems.  This has huge benefits to metabolic and genetic engineering, since we're (usually) always trying to minimize the impact of the organism's original biology on our engineered system.  Having amino acids and now bases that exist outside of the cell's usual machinery is a big step forward. Also, in regards to basic protein research, multiple non-natural amino acids could give protein engineers a lot more design space for rationally changing catalytic activity or directed evolution strategies.

Type 2 diabetes seems to have some sort of lack of response by cells to insulin itself.  Some type 2 diabetics do need insulin therapy and insulin therapy has been rising in popularity when treating type 2 diabetics, especially those with poorly controlled blood glucose levels when treated with other therapies.  I'd say there's potential for use in type 2 diabetics, but it likely wouldn't be preferred as the etiology of the diseases is somewhat different.

With over a million species described, insects are a treasure trove of diversity and represent boundless possibilities as research tools for answering fundamental questions in biology.   Current approaches for insect gene editing require microinjection of materials into early embryos, which is highly challenging in most species. This severely limits the application of gene editing to a great number of insect species, especially to those whose reproduction systems preclude access to early embryos for injection. A new  research shows us a simple and efficient method for insect gene editing by adult injection, which can be readily implemented in any laboratory and directly applied to a great diversity of non-model insect species.

Medical technologist here   It takes more than an hour because the specimen need to be sorted, caps have to be popped, swabs mixed in buffer, heat mixed for 10 minutes, cooled for 15 minutes, a master mix made up, samples from the bigger transfered to the master mix. Then, it takes an hour. This is for a "dirty pcr" method that lacks an extraction step where a more purified rna sample is isolated.  Start to finish for one run is at least 2.5 hours. The sorting and organizing takes, by far, longer than actually running the samples.

Yes all gene edits were made intentionally. Genes known to be particularly "pig-like" and therefore more antigenic to human immune cells were knocked out. Genes for porcine endogenous retroviruses (these are retroviruses that made their way into the pig genome and have been passed down through generations, which could pose a risk of reactivation and infection of human cells) were also knocked down.  Human genes which facilitate immune acceptance were edited in. It's a very co-ordinated science.

The CRISPR method involves recognition of a specific sequence of DNA bases, and replaces that specific sequence with one that is hardcoded into the CRISPR. In essence a CRISPR recognizes "atataggccat" and replaces it with "aataacgcgtt". This could pose an issue if the sequence is very short, but CRISPR sequences are rather long, which should practically eliminate any chance of modification in an unwanted location.

The condition being treated here, Leber's Congenital Amaeurosis, does not generally destroy all vision until several years after birth.  Typically, patients have at least rudimentary vision for long enough for the visual parts of the brain to form and organize based on visual input. And even though LCA is a rapidly progressing dystrophy, it often does not completely take away all vision, though what is left is sometimes no better than "count fingers" or "light perception only." Whatever edits are done to the DNA  by CRISPR are permanent. The issue is getting them to happen in the first place, and making sure they're the right ones. The reason blood diseases are the first to get a CRISPR therapy is that you can take bone marrow out of the patient, do CRISPR editing in the lab, and then put the edited cells back in the patient. That takes the challenge of making CRISPR work inside the human body out of the equation, so it's a much easier thing to perfect and scale up for commercial use.

Basically the CRISPR system is an adaptation on a bacterial immune system that targeted viruses. When a virus infects a bacteria, part of the viral DNA is cut out and encorporated into the bacterial DNA sort of as a record . When the virus reinfects the bacteria(or the descendents of that bacteria) this encorporated DNA is used as a guide for an enzyme that can cut the virus at the exact place the original viral DNA came from therfore destroying the virus. So what they do in CRISPR tech is basically decide on the 'guide DNA'. In this way you can decide to cut at almost any place on a genome. The natural repair mechanisms that usually deal with DNA that has been cut allows you to either just mutate that gene or you can add new DNA to replace the gene.

Yeah sort of. Something like non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is completely different from a B-cell lymphoma (in the blood, sort of). Human cells and tissues vary in a lot of ways, and the ways they might form into cancer also vary. These differences even exist within the same tissues.  Cancer really is a name for a large number of diseases (which can simplified be grouped as 'cells that begin proliferating a lot more than they should'). Treating different forms of cancer requires different means. 'A cure for cancer' is comparable to saying 'a cure for virus'. Universal cure is not an option unfortunately.

First step is likely going to be non-CRISPR eradication of bad genes, starting with the nasty stuff (degenerative diseases, fatal stuff, serious disabilities) and working towards the less serious stuff (color blindness, nearsightedness, etc) and eventually the costmetic stuff (stopping addiction, obesity, hair loss, body hair reduction, etc) It all comes down to how simple it is to identify and control the genes - some things we know are caused by a single gene (Hunters disease, Angelman syndrome, Huntingtons), while others we are still looking at possibly hundreds or thousands of genes being involved (Autism)

The HIV genome is not really that large. In fact all of its protein coding sequences are incredibly tightly packed and very sensitive to mutation. This is a good point, but do consider the rate of improvement we have seen in the past ten years or so. The development of parallel or similar tools to the original CRISPR has expanded significantly. Increasing the specificity of  these tools by requiring an additional base pair or two in the PAM sequence, or reducing off target effects, are all major areas of research. Unless it can be demonstrated that CRISPR will never avoid off target effects, it is reasonable to expect that within a few decades we could begin to see the beginnings of simple gene editing. This fellow was using existing gene expressions other humans already have, and inserting it into embryos. Not creating and integrating novel genes (ex. Monsanto) from across species and splicing them. You can't create radiation from a gene, but you could do something like change muscle fiber densities in humans to be like a chimpanzee. However unlike science fiction, there aren't "super" genes. They all have tradeoffs. Higher muscle fiber tends to equal less precise control. That being said designer babies will certainly happen at some stage, and certainly some optimal selection for higher metabolic rate, cancer resistance and other obvious gene expressions will be discovered.

That doesn't make any goddamned sense on so many levels. For one genetic modifications would be high effort, and it requires both a very good knowledge of genetics and being stupid enough to believe in "undesirables" being genetically linked. Second if you were capable of targetting whatever traits you could edit them out instead of going classic eugenicist.

The principle of unintended consequences always applies, and the more direct control we have over our food's genetics, the more those unintended consequences are going to stack up. Potentially fatal in the sense that some oocytes and embryonic stem cell lines were found to revert to the original maternal mtDNA composition (i.e. the mitochondrial replacement therapy didn't "take") and maternal mtDNA has mutations that result in potentially fatal mitochondrial disease. Put another way, the potentially fatal effects resulted from the diseased mother's mtDNA, not from mitochondrial replacement. If this phenomenon also occurs in children born following MRT, they would effectively be no worse off than if they were to be born without having received MRT.  There are other hypothetical risks of MRT which could lead to negative outcomes beyond just the treatment not working, but the authors of this paper did not find evidence of any of them in this study.

Yep! Muscle fibers are regenerated by a pool of stem cells called satellite cells which divide and fuse into muscle fibers upon muscle injury. Once they have fused however, they are unable to replicate and divide since they have to dedicate all of their resources to making the contractile machinery in muscle. So if you induce some mutation in the DNA of a muscle nuclei, it doesn't really matter because that mutation won't ever propagate or provide a replication advantage. It will eventually disappear once that muscle nuclei is eventually lost.
You could certainly do this by genetic engineering. But CRISPR just edits what is already present, whereas caffeine synthesis would require new genes.

That may seem obvious. But that does not happen. There are many copies of mitochondrial genome in a single cell. Typically when dysfunction occurs, that portion of the mitochondria and its genome associated are degraded.  Dysfunction overall occurs when many genomes become dysfunctional all at once, resulting from nuclear proteins essential for maintenance overall have mutations.   It is very unlikely all of these mutations will happen spontaneously within all mtDNA in a single cell and perpetuate throughout all of the mitochondria within all cells.

I mean, if you had even read paragraph one of the article, you'd know all of the answers to this, but I'll summarize.  The point was to prove whether flies find sex pleasurable, or whether there's a different driving force behind why creatures sexually reproduce. Flies can't detect red light, so they shined a red light into half of a room, and left the other half dark. Flies that entered the red portion only knew that they ejaculated, and they had a large tendency to stay there after that happened, indicating that they probably found it enjoyable. This tendency confirms that the driving force behind fly intercourse is one of pleasure, which tells us more about the behavior of flies, and is likely applicable to the rest of the natural world.

However, PTEN converges on a number of different pathways, so identifying one that promotes the regrowth effects seen here that doesnt also promote cancer will take a significant amount of additional research. I will also mention that small molecule targeting as opposed to gene targeting are about equal in risk vs reward ratio. With small molecules (the traditional treatment method) there is a much higher risk of side effects, bit we know a lot more about this methodology and can develop them more quickly. Gene therapy is much more new and could result in more complications in the future, especially if we are not careful with the genes we choose to modify, but it is also much more precise, if generally more expensive and transient in nature as a therapeutic.

One current therapeutic approach is to treat missense genetic diseases such as Sickle Cell.   The idea is to extract the patient's own bone marrow progenitor cells, edit the disease-causing mutation to the non-disease base pair, and then re-inject the cells back into the patient where they would re-enter the bone marrow niche and proliferate into non-diseased red blood cells.   It is an attractive idea because it wouldn't trigger the patient's immune system (since the patient's own cells are being used), and wouldn't require constant treatment (as the "fixed" BM cells would have a reasonable lifetime).

My child has rare genetic disorder called Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) type 1. At 2 weeks old, he received gene therapy treatment called zolgensma. He's now 8 months old and doing well, with physical limitations. Hes made amazing strides since treatment (head, neck, arm movement, etc). Without treatment, life expectancy is 2 years.  I'm ecstatic that gene therapy can be used for multiple disorders and cases. Gene therapy has given my son a chance at life. I stay hopeful that further advancements will turn these treatments into cures.

Definitely possible. In fact, that's sort of what the research that I took this gif from is doing. CAR-T cells targeting the CD19 protein have been very successful. But a fair number of tumors do escape the therapy, many by getting rid of the bit of CD19 protein the CAR-T cells target (either by downregulating CD19 expression, mutating the protein or inducing splicing changes to skip over the epitope). This paper found an additional target, BAFF-R, that also works very well in this type of tumor, and even in tumors that already evolved to escape CD19-directed CAR-T therapy. So you can imagine using something like this after CD19-CAR-T therapy. Or even modifying the genetic engineering to have the CAR-T cells simultaneously target both CD19 and BAFF-R, giving tumor cells less opportunities to escape.

I help to develop a very similar bone marrow transplant clinical trial as the one in the article and kerovon did a good job explaining the overview of the treatment. However, the genetically modified T cells are generally given as part of the infused cells (bone marrow transplant). Additionally, while this technology has great curative potential, the side effects are a major stumbling block to make this a more readily accessible treatment.  The side effects are generally worse for patients with more larger tumor burden because of a few issues. One is tumor lysis syndrome. These genetically modified cells do not kill and dispose of cells in a normal manner. Instead they basically just cut them open. This allows for the toxic inner components of cells to float around the body and can contribute to kidney problems, seriously low blood pressure, etc.

Non-viral transfection reagents work poorly on T cells.  PEI 25kda would be the gold standard for gene therapy.  It's very inefficient for T cells, however, and non-virally transfected genes are only expressed for a short amount of time (20 days at best).  T cells can't be readily transduced with adenoviruses because they lack the CAR receptor (not to mention, they will respond to the adenovirus itself).  There's not really that much of a difference between lenti and retroviruses in terms of where they insert their gene.  Lentiviruses are retroviruses.

The real problem is that qPCR has a lower sensitivity level and a bigger issue of false positives and negatives. It's more sensitive to things like heme in blood that inhibit the enzyme. qPCR also has decent background due to primer dimers and off target effects because of the temperature cycling. And if you breakdown the reagents required, this should cost the same as a qPCR test.  This has the added benefit of not requiring highly sophisticated instrumentation, so lyophilized kits could be taken into the field and performed in rural areas en masse.

One current therapeutic approach is to treat missense genetic diseases such as Sickle Cell.   The idea is to extract the patient's own bone marrow progenitor cells, edit the disease-causing mutation to the non-disease base pair, and then re-inject the cells back into the patient where they would re-enter the bone marrow niche and proliferate into non-diseased red blood cells.   It is an attractive idea because it wouldn't trigger the patient's immune system (since the patient's own cells are being used), and wouldn't require constant treatment (as the "fixed" BM cells would have a reasonable lifetime).

I'm a recovering ALL patient in a clinical trial at a major US hospital. I also had a bone marrow transplant. While this is huge progress, this isn't really a cure. The 4 patients that survived, all had bone marrow transplants shortly after the treatment described here. Chemo and radiation are very hard on the body, by damaging tissue and organs during the process. This type of cell treatment is showing to be much less toxic to the body, and provides a safer bridge to getting a transplant, assuming there is a donor that is a genetic match.  Also noteworthy, is that this treatment does not "cure" all ALL patients. Some patients, myself included, have additional chromosome defects (Philadelphia chromosome), that would not be saved by this treatment.

This stuff is a powerful tool in the fight against a lot of mosquito-born diseases.  The premise is that we can eliminate just the specific species of mosquitos that carries a long list of diseases. Since many other mosquito varieties fill the same niche in the ecosystem (in fact, often the 'bad' mosquito is an invasive species to begin with), there's little to no damage to everything else. At least, that's the premise.  One nice thing about this approach is that it can be applied in one region and then if there are negative effects, we can re-introduce the same species of mosquitos. It's not a one-way door.  But if it works, 400,000 fewer human deaths per year.

Well there are a few things. For one, antibody therapies have been successful against some forms of leukemia but ineffective against others. Also the immune system still has to follow all of its normal rules in order to fight off the cancer (which is not playing by normal rules). The genetically modified T cells contain a component called a Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR) which gives them the ability to combat against the cancerous cells in a new way. They no longer have to determine whether a target is "self-vs-nonself", they simply seek, destroy, and send signals for others to do the same. The fact that this technology doesnt determine self-vs-nonself allows for more efficient elimination of the cancer since cancer is infact your own body.

Balding is caused by a molecule called DHT (similar to testosterone) binding to receptors in your hair follicles called androgen receptors. Some people's androgen receptors are overly sensitive to DHT, which leads to a shrinkage of the follicle and causes baldness. This is actually a case where Ex-vivo gene therapy might work. By taking some of the patients cells, culturing them, replacing the allele responsible for the androgen receptor mutation, and putting them back, you might be able to cure baldness. The issue is, that is a lot of work and risk for one person for what is not a life threatening condition (not to minimize the issue, I know it sucks).

I don't think either of the two patients had radiation.  From what I see, they had been previously treated with just chemo. This is fairly different from stem cell therapy.  In stem cell therapy, you are trying to take stem cells and induce them to differentiate into your target cell. So, for instance, you pull out some of the mesenchymal stem cells from the patient, place them on an artificial scaffold shaped like their trachea, let them grow and differentiate into the cell layers needed, and then use that to replace the patients trachea (The first 2-3 replacements like this were recently done).

No. What we did before GMOs was Selective Breeding. Thats when humans breed plants or animals for a desired trait from the same species. Changes take generations to happen. Corn and Dogs are good examples of selective breeding.  Genetically Modified Organisms are organisms whose genetic material (DNA) has been changed. It would never occur naturally in the wild (or through selective breeding). Sometimes it involves adding genes from a difference species to obtain the desired result quickly. Most Papayas and Soybeans we use are Genetically Modified. Papayas were modified to save them from a deadly virus that was killing all the crops.

We also prioritize the macronutrients - NPK, but not the micronutrients. When those are lacking it can inhibit the plants ability to uptake macronutrients. A lot of the minerals are in most soils, but they aren't bioavailable to plants until certain soil life processes it (some even eat rock). Current farming methods destroy soil life so these micronutrients aren't available. There is also a depletion of carbon in soils, which houses the soil life, retains moisture while simultaneously allowing excess to drain, and acts as a glue for nutrients. Tilling removes it. That is starting to be addressed with cover crops and even some no-till, but they still kill the cover crop by spraying it, and said sprays kill soil life. The therapy described here would not be predicted to benefit people with ALS, since the gene it is rescuing is not implicated in ALS pathology. That said, people have begun to investigate gene therapy in ALS (in part motivated by the success of gene therapy for SMA). I am aware of at least one program - which targets C9orf72. Since ALS can be caused by a number of different mutations, the gene therapy approach would likely be done on a 'gene by gene' basis. It would also be complicated by the fact that although we are gaining a deeper understanding of which genes are mutated in ALS, we still don't always know how these mutations work (are they gain if function? Loss of function?). Understanding that will also be critical for gene therapy in ALS.

This is different than vaccination. Vaccines stimulate the immune system against a foreign pathogen and help foster immunological memory so the body will be better able to respond when it encounters the pathogen again. In this case, the researchers are using cancer cells modified to express a certain surface protein that can induce cell death in tumor cells with the corresponding receptor. It does not appear they are stimulating the immune system to clear the cancer cells.  Yes, I suppose it's always possible for engineered cells to become deranged if the modification does not occur as expected, but it should be quite rare. The CRISPR technology is relatively precise.  Also yes, cancerous cells do die the same way as other cells, although they may be harder to kill in some cases.

It's a completely different process, though. In selective breeding, specimens are bred together for their desirable traits to become more prominent. Still the same species, still what could, conceivably, occur naturally. With genetic modification, which is not the same as selective breeding, genes are typically pulled from one species and placed within another in a way which generates a desirable result, but could not have ever occurred naturally. That freaks some people out. Personally, i think it's great, but i also understand the concern some people have.

Just a tangent - but cancer can never truly be "eradicated" Infections such as polio can be eradicated - eliminate the infectious agent and you can't contract the infection. Hereditary diseases such as Huntington's can be eradicated, by editing the genome of all carriers, resulting in the faulty genotype ceasing to exist. Cancer is random mutation of a cell resulting in loss of replication regulation, and uncontrolled proliferation.  Because it's a random mutation it can occur in literally anyone - certain genotypes can make you more likely to mutate to a cancerous genotype, but everyone has some risk.  Short of eliminating the ability of our cells to mutate (which would have terrible consequences) we can't totally eradicate the risk of developing cancer.

MS treatment typically involves a different strategy. The disease is based on rogue T cells that attack the myelin sheath. Conventional treatment is through targeting and management of B cells (see ocrelizumab). CRISPR could potentially be applied to amplify expression of a certain protein that better regulates the rogue T cells. These treatment strategies would only halt progression of disease. Anyone with late- to end-stage disease would require regeneration of the myelin sheath, which is a territory which we have not yet reached with medicine.

It is not an ethical violation in and of itself, but genetic modification does bring up legal and ethical questions that should be explored without hyperbole, personal attacks, belittling, and demagoguery. GMO food's place, for example, in vertical integration, monoculture, and monopolies are not to be dismissed out of hand. Thankfully nothing seems out of hand yet, but there's the potential and we shouldn't be barred from discussing and debating in good faith.

There is certainly a stigma, yes. But the real reason it isn't used is not simply because of the stigma. Currently, the CRISPR-cas9 system results in many off-target effects, and it isn't completely known what causes these off-targets. Until these problems can be remediated (which will likely happen in the next 10-20 years), we can't readily utilize these technologies to make accurate and safe genetic modifications. Also, the stigma is not only in the west. The majority of Chinese scientists have been condemning this science all morning, and rightly so.

Viruses basically cut open your DNA and stick their own in. Crispr uses a similar thing to cut open your DNA and inject the correct sequence. In this case, it targets the messed up section, cuts it out, and replaces it with the normal (correct) sequence. Once you fix DNA, it should be OK because when the cell divides, it will replicate its now fixed DNA and its daughter cells won't have the mutation.  The struggle is, how do you get the treatment into the correct cells and make it target the right sequence faithfully. Also, many diseases can be caused by many different mutations that cause the same phenotype (effect) so you also would need to identify where and what the mutation is. But yea. If we master this, we can effectively erase genetic diseases.

Only in the level of specificity and control we have. They both have the same end goal of selecting genes that in some way make the crop more desirable, it's just the method of genetic manipulation that differs. With selective breeding the gene mutations are random, and we simply keep any that we like--that's how we have all of the radically different vegetables that all came from cabbage, ranging from brocolli to brussels sprouts. There's an expedited version of this process called mutation breeding, where mutations are randomly induced with radiation or chemicals, and then selectively bred or discarded based on the outcome. All we're doing with transgenics is skipping ahead and directly adding the genetic mutations that we want, instead of selecting out of whatever the random grab bag gives us.

Any technology can be misused. Your hypotheticals here pretty far-fetched though. Gene therapy is complex and expensive. The far more likely scenario is that many people who want and need the treatment will not be able to afford it.

Swapping out a whole chromosome is way different than fixing a bad gene.  I'm pretty sure we're no where near doing that - and even if we were, it would quite possibly have quite a few unintended consequences along with it.

You get people who think like this because there is a concerted effort in the field to change definitions and mislead people. Pharma shills are trying to say that it's not gene therapy by saying, "Well we aren't changing your DNA like most gene therapies do so it doesn't count." They rely on the average person being too uninformed to know that DNA aren't the only things in you with genes so that they don't have to say that they are instead changing your genes in your RNA.

For your second question, as far as my understanding of it goes, it doesn't really matter if the RNA is translated to a protein since the protein you would get would be a truncated version anyway. So yes, a proportion of the RNA may get translated but it doesn't matter. However, what is important to understand is that RNA that is complementarily bound to DNA is incapable of undergoing translation. Hence, only a fraction of the RNA would get translated, and even if it does, what's big deal!

During cell division the telomeres shrink as copying starts at the point that the copying mechanism latches on to the telomere, that point is not necessarily the beginning, once the telomere has been shortened beyond a certain point cell division gets less and less successful. So keeping the telomeres at a healthy length should address at least one cause of aging.

The problem is that these cancer-causing abilities can be caused my many different mutations and even in one patient different tumours can have different mutations... Basically, these processes that are impaired consist of whole complex networks of signalling that can be 'broken' at multiple points. On the other hand, some types of cancer (such as acute promyelocytic leukemia) are caused by broken chromosomes that fuse to another chromosome, which are really specific mutations that might be targeted using these methods. Another example is colorectal cancer (of your gut) that has some very specific genes that are mutated (APC, P53, KRAS and so on). So definitely potential for CRISPR but applications in the near future are limited to some types of cancer.

The problem is that these cancer-causing abilities can be caused my many different mutations and even in one patient different tumours can have different mutations... Basically, these processes that are impaired consist of whole complex networks of signalling that can be 'broken' at multiple points. On the other hand, some types of cancer (such as acute promyelocytic leukemia) are caused by broken chromosomes that fuse to another chromosome, which are really specific mutations that might be targeted using these methods. Another example is colorectal cancer (of your gut) that has some very specific genes that are mutated (APC, P53, KRAS and so on). So definitely potential for CRISPR but applications in the near future are limited to some types of cancer.

Woah there. Genetic changes aren't heritable. Not when they're done in body cells that is. There's a difference between the body cells and the sex cells aka. sperm and eggs. You can change the cells of the mothers or fathers body however you like but it won't have any impact on the offspring. You can only make heritable changes if you modify the sperm or egg cells. And genetic changes being "contagious" makes absolutely no sense.

Your title missed the 'p', which is kinda significant. No full autosomal chromosome monosomy is compatible with life. P arms of chromosomes represent the smaller proportion of the chromosome (and may involve no protein-coding genes, in the case of acrocentric chromosomes) - for chromosome 6 specifically, the p arm is around 60Mbp versus the q arm being around 110Mbp. Secondly, while nowhere is sharing the specific deletion, it's most likely a small and proximal deletion, rather than what the article has illustrated - various 6p deletions have been reported, typically involving facial dysmorphia, brain, heart and kidney issues, sight and hearing problems and intellectual disability. (Also "cry-do-cat" syndrome is kinda killing me from a 'genetic education' page)

Traditional attenuated virus vaccines introduce virus.  The virus enters the cell.  If it's an RNA virus that doesn't need mechanisms from the nucleus to replicate, it will then begin replicating, producing mRNA to make proteins (including spike proteins).  Some of these processes will interfere with host cell's internal processes to make the cell focus on cranking out virus.  Necessarily, a live attenuated virus will produce the same mRNA to be translated into spike protein as exists in the mRNA vaccine.  The live attenuated virus vaccine just also does a lot more than that.

My problem with this is that it has a potential to create a dependency on the company selling the sterile males. What's worse is that the mosquitos' natural predators are likely to drop in population as well due to the smaller food supply. Ultimately it would balance back out, but not before political pressure leads governments to start reintroducing the males again.

Hey, I'm one of the authors on this paper.  The main difference is that Cas9 introduces small mutations.  Cas9 is also able to make large deletions if you combine at least two targets.  But the efficiency can be pretty low. This approach makes a large spectrum of deletions with a single guide, in a more or less predictable way.  This is a general problem in genetics research where you want to delete a region of DNA but you don't know where the important bits are. And if the technology can be modified a bit and controlled a bit more, you could use a similar approach to decrease the length of certain repetitive regions which are known to cause diseases. It has a long way to go before it's fully 'useful', but at least conceptually it can be an improvement in certain applications.
